Though predictable, it at least tries to put on a fresh face to a tiresome old feelgood story.
The music is the movie's best feature, but even that's not much...
Though it wears out its welcome as it teeters rather than rocks toward the finish line, there is something inherently enticing in the old "let's put on a show" formula it utilizes.
What keeps Bandslam afloat is the way its sweet moments find weird ways of stepping into convention.
Fun without too much camp.
A message that never gets old: On stage or in high-school hallways, sometime it's the losers that turn out to be the real winners.
Surprisingly, it's Vanessa Hudgens who brings the film to life, creating an original and believable brooding teen.
The surprise of the summer, and one of the year's overlooked gems.
...Bandslam remains under-appreciated...
Equal parts John Hughes and Cameron Crowe with a little bit of Spike Jonze tossed in.
It isn't very witty - although it's supposed to be - and it isn't really satire, in the sense of Singin' in the Rain or The Band Wagon.
It's Fred and Ginger and in color, but the movie's pretty bad.
This is a weak reteaming, unfortunately, and it's the screenplay by Betty Comden and Adolph Green which does that.

Astaire and Rogers last teaming, and full of wit, music, dance, and comedy.
Though one of their weakest teaming, it's worth seeing this late (and last) Astaire-Rogers musical for historical reasons; Rogers replaced the ailing Judy Garland.
...of interest as a possible peek into Rogers and Astaire's actual working relationship.
Barkleys of Broadway reunites one of filmdom's happiest teamings Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers. They have had happier pictures than this one.
The material itself has a formulaic solo-bioplay rhythm neither performer nor director can fully elude.
Effortless charm has always been a characteristic of Plummer's performance, and here he wields it to considerable effect.
In the hands of an actor of such calibre as Plummer, it is riveting stuff. And often hilarious, risqu, even coarse on occasion

Erik Canuel, who directed and adapted the work, employs a host of cinematic techniques to enhance Plummer's spell-binding turn as a crotchety has-been who, in 1942, attempts to revive his career by playing Richard III.
Director Erik Canuel fails to deliver us from the inevitable hermeticism of the material.
Despite some stylistic missteps, showcase for Plummer's Tony-winning performance will captivate theater fans.

God, I love Plummer's performance -- the twiddling fingers, the tipsy sway of the head, the reverberating roar, as well as the pathos of a man who can't stop acting long enough to hear the cry of his own soul.
A wistful look at faded dreams and opportunities lost due to both the vagaries of the business and self-sabotage.
This isn't a film, it's a recording of canned ham-tasty, certainly, but creaky nonetheless.
It was brilliant as a one-man stage show; it was never a good candidate for film.

Mr. Plummer stumbles beautifully, poignantly and often, leering and searching through a haze of memory or, with concern edged with panic, calling for "a line, a line" much as Richard III calls for a horse.
Plummer is the one-man show at the center of this one-man vehicle. He will leave you stunned and cheering.
As an acting masterclass, it's educational and entertaining.
While Plummer acts his heart out, the script becomes one punchline after another.
Christopher Plummer works hard to give us his idea of John Barrymore in this record of a theatrical tour-de-force, which is more dramatically florid than biographically enlightening.
Plummer's Barrymore shows flashes of glory as he delivers bits and pieces of various Shakespearean roles.
Plummer is marvelous, flitting between reminiscence and Shakespearean recitation as a gifted artist aware of his own wretchedness.
You wish you could be seeing this performance live, as it's meant to be seen - but lacking that, "Barrymore" on the big screen provides its own thrills.
In spite of creating a CGI world around Plummer, much is lost in this translation, making an impressive performance from him seem inert.
Plummer is phenomenal, but be warned: you really have to like one-person shows in order to enjoy this 84-minute tour de force.
The interest is in Plummer himself-who he is, what he can do.
Think of it as one great performer saluting another.

Plummer commands the stage as easily and firmly as Barrymore must have. He makes us believe that Barrymore would indeed, as he tries to reach deep into his past and revive Richard, keep recalling his wives or breaking in to sing a pop song of the day.
Danny Baron's film awkwardly melds Bollywood romcom tropes with a half-hearted critique of the GMO industry.
Watching it is something like watching a play's first full dress rehearsal or a gangly baby deer's initial efforts to stand, where it's the effort that's more engaging than the achievement itself.
Ca-Ca Land.
...the dreadful Bollywood meets Wilson Phillips music video nobody asked for and certainly don't need.
The movie starts out heedless in its desire to charm, but it winds up feeling constrained by self-consciousness, and more's the pity.
There's nothing wrong about sending the message of fighting corporate greed but it's through execution of the material that ultimately fails Basmati Blues.
Basmati Blues clearly wants to be a Western take on a Bollywood movie. In reality, it's a "Bollywoof" movie, which is to say, a Bollywood wannabe that's a real dog.
A broadly played though vibrantly photographed musical romantic-comedy that fails to find a happy medium between cute-and-clever and simply cloying.
An amiable misfire.
[O]ne might see the movie's clunky story, its forced humor, its awkward editing rhythms, and its garish visuals as intentional parts of the movie's attempted charm.
Basmati Blues only scores so many points for not making its heroine a struggling magazine writer in the Big Apple.
Basmati Blues is the kind of easily forgiven early career move that is best released on home video and forgotten.
"Basmati Blues" is one of those movies that isn't terrible but still leaves you wondering why it exists.
Part hamfisted critique of Big Ag, part strained romantic comedy, and part insipid musical that's not much like the Bollywood tribute it's meant to be. An accidental parody of itself.
This attempt at an American-style Bollywood musical is earnest at best and sappy, nave, and overly sweet at worst; it does have lively moments, but it mainly inspires aggravation and eye-rolling.
Cross-cultural musical romantic comedy stirs together some pleasing ingredients but falls short of its expansive ambitions.

Basmati Blues isn't nearly as bad as some of the online buzz might indicate...and that's actually unfortunate. Instead of vying for a so-bad-it's-entertaining categorization, it falls squarely into the hell of cinematic mediocrity.
Basmati Blues is an inoffensive trifle. It does not warrant outrage; it's not bold enough to risk it. Yet there is some heart, and undoubtedly, some ambition.
Larson's charismatic screen presence can't elevate such woefully lackluster material.
A shaky, Bollywood-style musical worth a watch just to see Oscar-winner Brie Larson give it her all.
Larson's work in Basmati Blues is much like the film as a whole-not great by any means but undeniably charming nevertheless.
Larson is cute but this is far beneath her talents.
A simple American comedy production that tries to present Hollywood audiences with a taste of Indian Bollywood... [Full review in Spanish]
But Basmati Blues, even if well-intentioned, does not rise above the cliches to find its heart.
Yes, as an Indian critic, I can confirm that Brie Larson's film is unbelievably and insultingly racist.
The movie is not only one of those stereotypical films about India, but also one of those 'white savior comes to rescue Third World village' type of films.
Basmati Blues isn't going to win any Oscars, but I finished the movie happier than when I started.
I love Brie Larson. I love Donald Sutherland. I love musicals. I quite like rice. I don't like Basmati Blues.
I didn't know whether to be deeply offended or simply sit back and bask in the goofy, tone-deaf glory of Basmati Blues.
The dorky, jingoistic charm wins points just for daring to dress the team in red, white and blue Kangols while the judges scream, "Korea strikes back with an aerial assault!"
Remarkably, the highlight of Benson Lee's film, essentially a fiction reboot of his Planet B-Boy, isn't the scene where Chris Brown gets punched in the face.
A film steeped in the streetwise hip-hop culture should have an edge, but Battle of the Year is safer and softer than Drake's last album.
The miracle of the new 3-D dance film "Battle of the Year" is how it can be so relentlessly boring while there is so much frenetic activity on screen.
The raison d'tre of popping-and-locking scenes is trumped by tired team-building bathos, whose flagrancy is anything but conducive to spreading the film's hug-it-out bro-love.
The story is a derivative quilt, patching together cliches from every sports movie since 1976.
This 3-D spectacle is less the dance movie that's going to make b-boying cool again than a shill for sponsors' gear.
At the risk of sounding 100, I think it's regrettable this film had to be shot in digital 3-D.
A frenetic mess that makes Breakin' 2: Electric Boogaloolook like a Fellini film.
Battle of the Year is too inept to make this tired premise sing.
If you can get past the mountain of cliches and poor acting and hackneyed story lines and the fact that someone let Chris Brown be in a movie, "Battle of the Year" is actually ... still pretty awful.

Fatally frontloaded with endless training montages, awfully written, indifferently acted drama, sports-film platitudes and jaw-dropping product placements that only the hardiest of viewers will make it through to the payoff.
Bland and boring are not the adjectives you hope for from a movie starring Josh Holloway as an alcoholic coaching a team of young breakdancers to the world championship (in 3D!).
Chris Brown gets punched in the face, so it's not a total wash.
so familiar that you half expect Julia Stiles and Channing Tatum to show up and start hoofing
Everything about Benson Lee's predictable dance flick "Battle of the Year" strikes me as old.
Destined to please only bad movie buffs desperate for a fix of awful dialogue, blatant product placement, and clunky exposition.
It isn't good by any stretch of the imagination, but B-movie lovers who like their dance movies flashy, fun, and spectacularly dumb shouldn't mind.
Battle of the Year crams so many clichs into its 109 minutes that you just know it will end with a sports movie freeze-frame. And it does!

It's undeniable that the good-natured "Afterschool Special" vibe here plays to the film's corny strengths, and the dancing is impressive. So much so that it's almost impossible not to cheer during the final round.
Not badly executed, but not the least bit original either.
There's not nearly enough quality material to make Battle of the Year recommendable to anyone other than the most hard-core of dance fanatics.
The bar for urban-flavoured dance movies has already been set pretty low, but Battle Of The Year effortlessly leans back and limbos on below it.

The actual dancing scenes are occasionally electrifying, if far too sparse, but other than that and the welcome sight of co-star Chris Brown getting clocked in the face, the film barely gets off the ground, much less sticks the landing.
Passable drama has great dancers but no originality.

A dead-in-the-soul cash grab of a movie set in the competitive world of B-boy dancing that thinks clichs, phony melodrama and product placement can substitute for real storytelling and actual characters.
Battle of the Year clearly features lots of brilliant dancers, and I'd be lying if I said I didn't enjoy watching them move. But you wish there were more dancing here.
Should satisfy the planet of b-boys and girls to whom it thoroughly preaches, while amusing anyone else who simply can't ignore the promise of an all-corn buffet.
The movie's inability to showcase its greatest asset, the grace and control of its dancers, is its most conspicuous failing.
The 3-D is a pain, and the excitable editing, slo-mo and speeded-up action frustrate attempts to watch the athleticism on display ...
This screenplay makes the "Step Up" dance films come off like Shakespeare in comparison. (Full Content Review for Parents also available)
Eschewing shaded characterization and often basic sense, while establishing what should be the high-water mark for most crotch-grabbing in a single film in 2013.
After months of patient waiting, 2013 has finally produced a movie that's so bad it's good.
Everything else in this pedestrian dance drama is either absurdly corny or just plain moronic, though the feature does win points for being so earnest with its hopeless pile of clichs.

its dramatization of a U.S. dream team's journey to the international showcase is leaden with predictable character types and storytelling clichs, neither of which its well-executed but oddly infrequent dance sequences are able to overcome.
Introduce female choreographer. Explore misogyny for 15 seconds. Become uncomfortable with ideas. Disappear female choreographer.
Athletic dancing and a patriotic theme make this movie better than it should be.
Filled with fancy, if frenetic footwork but weighed down by all-too-familiar plot/characters/dialogue.
In particular, as mentioned, the dance sequences are a mess, which is the kiss of death for a film in this genre.
Battle of the Year is no Step Up 3D. But then, what is?
If director Werner Herzog can do it with 'Rescue Dawn' and 'Little Dieter Needs to Fly,' why can't director Benson Lee?
Like those it imitates, the film includes some energetic dance sequences and formulaic plotting that culminate in the obligatory final competition.
Battle of the Year would rather use crowd-shot cutaways to convince you of the dancers' prowess than focusing on the stage.
Dismal, clich-ridden stuff.
What could've been a fun '80s throwback ends up more frustrating that it's worth.
I didn't think it was possible, but "Battle of the Year" is more pandering than the entire "Step Up" series combined...
Josh Holloway tries his hardest, God bless him, but Battle of the Year 3D can't even be enjoyed as a blissfully dumb entry in its genre.
Even when a dance movie is following the formula as closely as Battle of the Year does, occasionally something you won't get to see anywhere else slips through.
Despite the reasonable dancing scenes and passable acting by singer Chris Brown, Battle Of The Year is a string of clichs, stock characters and unbearable melodrama.
Not only does it fail to use 3D, with its rapid edits, but the dramatic stuff is poorly edited and sound mixed as well.

Characters are not developed enough. You don't feel for them. Result being, you end up as mere spectators instead of well-wishers. While the film preaches 'passion' for whatever you do, it is exactly what seems to be missing from it.
Proof that any movie can get made somehow.
The young dancers' undeniable skill and athleticism is squandered in this formulaic, overly familiar dance movie.
Instead of allowing his film to be uplifted by dance, Lee burdens it with a cringe-worthy dramatic narrative.
Mmmm-hmmm, it's on. Again.
Although it's grotesque to see pre-teens stomping in underground warehouse-battle settings, at least Battlefield America's racial politics are interesting.
'Cringe-inducing' doesn't even begin to describe it.
Even the most forgiving viewers may feel like they've been underestimated - and underserved.
If you're looking for a tough, streetwise film about urban kids who get together to enter a national hip-hop dance competition, "Battlefield America" is not your movie.
Earnest emotions can't quite trump an awkward approach in Chris Stokes' followup to 2004's "You Got Served."
The teams seem to be competing for little more than bragging rights and one of those giant "Toddlers & Tiaras" trophies.
Slapdashly assembled and lacking in dance thrills.
This hip-hoppy dance-off melodrama is about as funky as an Amish funeral.
Watching stage-parented poseurs play at being punks, mugging for the camera and talking sass to every adult, is not most people's idea of time well spent at the movies.
A pic so thoroughly generic as to suggest a contraption assembled from spare parts with the aid of a how-to manual.

This is one battle where everyone involved loses.

...despite the title of the doc, which conjures up a madcap, heartbreaking tale, the film is a mostly workmanlike biopic that unfortunately can never match the energy of the subject it's trying to capture
Booker sparkles in the archival performance clips, and director Lily Keber wisely homes in on his live solo performances, bringing out his character and talent.
A sympathetic portrait of a genuinely idiosyncratic, outrageous individual.
[A] richly enjoyable documentary tribute.
Bayou Maharajah is worth watching for the performance footage alone.

[Booker] backed a huge number of musicians.. But his solo work -- shown here in rollocking, flamboyant archive performances -- allowed him to give full flight to his infectious and innovative mix of jazz, blues and classical.
Overall, though, Keber's film feels like an honourable attempt to tidy up after and make order of its subject's spiralling chaos.
In the music business, 'legend' is an over-used word: see this and understand what it means.
movie_title: BB King: The Life of Riley

review_content: Conscientious documentary toasting and contextualising blues guitarist BB King's life and work.
movie_title: BB King: The Life of Riley

review_content: [An] authoritative British documentary on [King's] long, impressive career.
movie_title: BB King: The Life of Riley

review_content: An intuitive and appealing documentary about the life of one of the world's most recognised Blues musicians, but BB King: The Life of Riley sometimes grows a bit repetitive and its chronological sequence is rather bland.
movie_title: BB King: The Life of Riley

review_content: Too many people know this man as just the source vocalist from Moby's classic 'Natural Blues'; hopefully this will change that.
movie_title: BB King: The Life of Riley

review_content: [King] is unfailingly articulate, gentlemanly and modest but this is a movie where more music, less talk would definitely have been an improvement.
movie_title: BB King: The Life of Riley

review_content: It would have been nice if the movie had allowed voices less fannish than those of King's peers and childhood friends to make the case for the signficance of 'The King of the Blues.'
movie_title: BB King: The Life of Riley

review_content: A dignified and wistful look at the unusual life, difficult career and lasting influence of singer-songwriter Townes Van Zandt.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: A loving and beautifully rendered portrait of one of America's largely unheralded artists.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: Loving but frank.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: Margaret Brown has directed a tender, impressionistic film biography about the Texan singer-songwriter Townes Van Zandt.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: Brown has put together a heartbreaking yet inspiring portrait of a transcendently tragic artist through home movies, family scrapbooks, live performances and interviews with ex-wives, record producers, and peers.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: Both frustrating and touching.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: To her vast credit, Brown doesn't attempt to psychoanalyze Van Zandt, or linger over the dark times in his short life in Be Here to Love Me. She instead keeps the focus where it should be: on the lasting gift of Townes Van Zandt's 30-year career.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: Brown's film evinces a tender, yet unsparing scrutiny of its subject's idiosyncrasies without getting too caught up in the romance of ruin.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: The songs burn with a dark fire, yet there are moments when Van Zandt is less Bob Dylan than David St. Hubbins.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: It's Van Zandt's family that provides the film's most memorable moments, from the second wife who declared life with him 'a bummer' to the children still trying to reconcile the great artist with the very mortal man.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: It's a portrait of a man who never got his full due while he lived -- and whose memory will be served well by its loving documentation.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: ...an excellent introduction to [Townes] Van Zandt's life and music.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: An unnarrated collection of gently told reminiscences that rove impressionistically, the film touches on various points in a career that remained a well-kept secret from the start, when Van Zandt began performing in the late 1960s.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: Vivid yet impressionistic, Margaret Brown's film tribute to the singer-songwriter Townes Van Zandt brings the late musician and his career into rare focus.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: Unlike many music documentaries, this is not a drab, talking-heads affair but a portrait assembled from evocative images and songs.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: A sobering but compassionate look at a man who ultimately might have been even more troubled than gifted.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: Brown weaves together audio footage and taped interviews that show a man whose proximity to death had calcified into a sharp blade of self-deprecating wit.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: ...required viewing for Van Zandt fans, probably required for country music fans, and even of interest to those with no great affection for either.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: Rather than connecting all the chronological dots, Brown has fashioned Van Zandt's balm-to-the- brokenhearted legacy into potent cinematic poetry.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: A less-than-satisfying examination of the country singer's art, career and demons.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: Manages a pretty fair portrait of Van Zandt and his personal demons, pressures and joys.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: A documentary that in its spirit and feel catches some of the vulnerability and naive optimism of its subject, Van Zandt.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: Van Zandt comes across as humble, witty, empathetic, sympathetic and very, very gifted.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: [An] honest, sobering and poignant tribute to a tortured talent who died young and left behind a treasure chest of songs.

review_content: He may not have been a good guy, but fellow musicians tend to focus on his work and they can't say enough good things about his talent. They sing his praises and sing his songs.

review_content: Van Zandt gets his own documentary

review_content: Loving but unflinching documentary on celebrated singer and songwriter Townes Van Zandt.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: While the film lacks polish, there's enough good material and good performances to keep everything on track.

review_content: A surprisingly deep understanding of an otherwise obscure artist.

review_content: This may not be a solid biography, but it feels true.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: A textured, elegiac, and deeply plangent music documentary. Brown's film, never exposing Van Zandt to too much harsh light, preserves this enigma just enough that it makes you want to go back to the music after you've caught these glimpses of the man.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: The film feels most authentic when it talks about the exhilaration and the freedom Van Zandt and other musicians feel when they cut off ties to family and home to make a songwriter's life on the road.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: Best of all, there is beautifully preserved in-concert footage, particularly a 1995 Amsterdam gig...

Beaches is a bicoastal crowd-pleaser, a tenderhearted, two-hanky melodrama brightened with Bette Midler's sass and sweetened with her songs. Barbara Hershey (formerly Barbara Seagull) lends class to the unlikely equation.
With its mix of drama, comedy, and music, the film leaves behind a rainbow of delectable emotions.
Chick-flick extreme, heavy on the syrup.
breaks your heart
Horrible... just horrible.
Vile trash.
I enjoyed the first forty-five minutes of Beaches. Beyond that, I kept looking at my watch wondering when it was ever going to end.
There are few horrors as singularly terrifying as this movie.
...it seems obvious that certain audiences will get a whole lot more out of it than others.
Even though tear-jerking has never been so blatant, your tears of laughter are replaced, dammit, by tears of grief.
Maudlin & weepy with tender performances by Midler and Hershey.
[An] engaging tearjerker.
The film's oily overdefinition of various class and cultural categories is strident enough to betray a condescending attitude toward the audience.

Garry Marhsall's unbearabaly schmaltzy and stereotyical medlodrama contrasts a brassy Jewish singer with an elegant WASPy socialite that even actresses like Bette Midler and Barbara Hershey cannot elevate or rescue.
Make some popcorn and get out the Kleenex.
Midler's singing is the only pleasant part of the film. The rest of it you've seen and heard before -- and better.
Beaches is bloodless, and Garry Marshall's direction, which might have given it style, is completely competent and entirely without personality.
For all of its insistence on the open, even gushing, expression of feeling, Beaches finally seems a little bit sneaky.
Beaches is a trite, maudlin, and terribly superficial effort of the sub-made-for-TV quality, an insult to anyone who has ever befriended another human being.
Bette Midler and Barbara Hershey give lively performances, but the screenplay is dreary.
Barbara Hershey is wasted in a boring role.
Beaches, despite its flaws, delivers an appealing message on the enduring quality of friendship.
Anything for a laugh, anything for a tear, and nothing much authentic.
As a film, Beaches is a contradictory mishmash of moods and intentions. However, the movie's weaknesses are the record's strengths.

Beaches epitomises the sort of triple-strength, three-hankie work you can expect from American women with three names and gives the lie to those who thought they stopped making women's pic heartstring-tuggers.
This drama is at its best when Midler gives free rein to her character rather than when it slips into schmaltz.
You've seen this four million times before but not with Midler wisecracking and singing and shaking her way through a whole movie -- or with Hershey as a pulp vision of monied beauty.
Beaches celebrates our friendships. And it's not afraid to be schmaltzy.
I prefer Midler in these sorts of roles.
Interesting way of looking at a long-dead culture first coming to life.

Without question, this is a Night to remember.

These three-minute singles still feel vibrant and alive.
It now strikes one as very much a product of its time, but it still has many pleasures.
Director Richard Lester's pop masterpiece is back and better than ever.
The rock and roll movie against which all others are measured.
Charged with vitality, and inventiveness.
A kinetic musical extravaganza that proved to detractors there was more to the Beatles than mop-tops and melodic pop hooks.
The film is mad, mad and crazy, shrewdly designed for the teenage and calculated also to attract the curious and the oldsters who enjoy this sort of thing.
A Hard Day's Night conveys not just a joy in music and The Beatles, but a joy in cinema.
One of the great life-affirming landmarks of the movies.
In A Hard Day's Night, the Beatles, in song after song, pay homage to the faith of love, and that faith connects them to something ancient, lending this topspin musical its near oracular beauty.
Captured forever here in a filmic bottle is pop-culture lightning, not only Beatles magic and energy but the spirit of the early 60s that sustained it.
An hour and a half of pure, chaotic bliss.
You thought, like I once did when I was too young and punk rock to care, that the Beatles were irrelevant old people who should just go away. This will convince you they were cool.
From the opening chords of the title song played over the group bemusedly fleeing from their fans, A Hard Day's Night creates pure, infectious joy.
A comedy classic that cross- pollinated Jean-Luc Godard with the four Marx brothers.
To watch the movie, and to enjoy such pop music classics as 'All My Loving' and 'She Loves You' is not merely to saunter down Memory or Penny Lane, but to drink at pop's headwaters.
Richard Lester's tangential, effortlessly clever ode to the Fab Four, given the re-mastered print and soundtrack treatment, still feels fresh and alive.
No movie of the 1960s catches that era's irreverent joy and exuberance as much as director Richard Lester's Beatlemania saga.
The film is still entertaining and certainly easy to watch, especially if you have anything more than a passing interest in the band during their early days of worldwide fame.
We loved them -- yeah, yeah, yeah. Now we can love them all over again.
Finally, I know what a feel-good movie is.
Remains a must-see for any Beatles fan, anyone who enjoys intelligent comedy, or anyone interested in seeing a moment of history caught poignantly on celluloid.
More than anything else, the movie is a snapshot of how much fun Beatlemania really was.
Has survived the years like a Disney cartoon classic.
It captures almost everything good about its time.
The film was easy to dance to and had a sound comic rhythm. It still does.
Don't even try to keep a smile off of your face and a song out of your heart while watching the film. It's just not possible.
It's the exuberance of 'Can't Buy Me Love' and the chiming harmonies of 'If I Fell' that will leave a moony smile on your face when the show is over.
Filled with unforgettable moments, most having to do with the music.
To watch the final concert segment is to look back decades and realize, as you do seeing vintage footage of Duke Ellington or Frank Sinatra or John Coltrane, that it's never really gotten any better.
The music video by which all other music videos must be judged. And none top it.
In its own fab way, A Hard Day's Night was a pivotal point in British filmmaking.
Still feels brand spanking new, and way cool.
Younger fans can see what Beatlemania was really all about.
It was a movie very much of its time, and in encapsulating that time so well, it has become a film for all times.
A Hard Day's Night remains a highly lovable movie.
This delightful cinematic masterpiece answers the question "Do we still love them?" with a resounding "Yeah! Yeah! Yeah!"
Filled with funny lines and modest gags, A Hard Day's Night also presents the Beatles in performance within the candid framework of the movie.
Richard Lester's innovative film, the Beatles' debut feature, is a timewarp memento of that brief 1963-4 phase in their history known as Beatlemania.
Great band, great music, great film. Not only that, it remains a fascinating portrait of Britain on the cusp of change.

Shot in a mock-documentary style, with little or no plot to drive it, A Hard Day's Night was a refreshing, fast-cut glimpse into the lives of the Fab Four as they rode the runaway train of sudden global success.
One of the most influential films of the past 40 years gets the spit and polish for a reissue -- and it still hasn't aged at all.

Not only has this film not dated, it may even look fresher than it did in 1964; the zigzag cutting and camera moves, the jaunty ironies and pop-celebrity playfulness, are all standard issue now on MTV and its offspring.
Beatles fans will get a kick out of this, but those who don't worship at the Beatle shrine may be a bit flustered by its complete lack of a plot and incomprehensible accents.
a priceless piece of history, a commemoration of a time when pop stars weren't jaded and calculating, fans weren't psychotic and music was more important than marketing.
A time capsule preserving the Fab Four's charisma, joy, and youthful exuberance.
The deadpan humor and non-sequiturs are delivered with such dry perfection you often find yourself rewinding to see if you really heard what you think you did. (And you did.)
It's hard to estimate the effect the film had on the future of movies, television, and society in general.
A love letter to innocence and euphoria and the sheer lifting joy of great pop music.
A breezy slice of silliness that pretty much has the Beatles playing themselves.
...if you don't like the Beatles, you don't like rock 'n' roll. And if you don't like A Hard Day's Night, you don't like movies.
Captures the Beatles when they still looked like they were having fun, back before drugs and psychedelia and Yoko Ono took effect.
The result still seems fresh and different decades later.
Everything about this movie is a smile.
The kind of timeless artifact that, decades after its making, still hits the senses like a burst of fresh air.
It's a fine conglomeration of madcap clowning in the old Marx Brothers' style, and it is done with such a dazzling use of camera that it tickles the intellect and electrifies the nerves.
The cinema has had many landmarks, but few have been as entertaining.
That Lester and the Beatles got away with the irreverent and superb Hard Day's Night is, by today's standards, a miracle.
See it for no other reason than the fact that it's all too rare you can spend 87 minutes smiling and feeling positive about life.
It's by no stretch of the imagination a good film, but it gets over as a curio and a landmark in modern Western culture.
The mop-tops are likeably relaxed, with Lennon offering a few welcome moments of his dry, acerbic wit.
American-born director Richard Lester serves up a helping of what, on this side of the pond, we came to think of as kicky, mod British filmmaking.
The film moves with such joy, humor and fluidity that you can't help getting swept up in the frenzied action.

Director Richard Lester and writer Alun Owen (who has never gotten the credit he deserves) treat us to a fanciful day in the life of the Beatles, filmed in 1964 at (they thought) the peak of the Fab Four's popularity.
For fans this is a chance to enjoy The Beatles' legendary music and charisma with unprecedented clarity.
The best British film of the 1960s.
Beatles classic as fabulous as the Fab Four.
Richard Lester's inventive, humorous mockumentary of the Beatles had a huge impact, forever changing the definition and limits of the musical movie genre.
At best, it is fun. But "fun" is not an aesthetic experience: fun remains on the surface. I have nothing against the surface. But it belongs where it is and shouldn't be taken for anything else.
Worth re-watching over and over again to relive the Beatles music, personalities, and lasting legacy.
Even when the band plays away from private eyes or songs simply play over disconnected footage of them having fun, the strength of their songcraft is stirring.
Of its time, sure, but eternally entertaining.
Make a date to catch this on the big screen and be rewarded with pure magic.
Let's talk about joy, and about wistfulness, because one so often trails the other, and both are woven into the DNA of A Hard Day's Night.
An anarchic, ground-breaking breath of fresh air that weaves a fictional romp around a chaotic day in the life of the Fab Four as they try to make it to their big show.
A Hard Day's Night looks chaotic and slapdash enough (and just occasionally, for me, depressing enough) to count as an experimentalist or underground movie.
The simple joys of mucking about are captured in this madcap concert tour farce with the Beatles.
Richard Lester was the man born to direct this kinetic, kaleidoscopic comedy-with-songs, starring a quartet still fresh from the first gusts of chart-topping fame.
Comes bouncing at you from every angle, rubbery and untameable with the joys of teenagehood.
Rejected the status quo with an irreverent, quick-cutting documentary style that could fairly be described as mod, rocking and mocking.
It's more than a movie; it's a key artifact (- must or muss) of a cultural phenomenon.
At a time when Elvis and Cliff were still making old-style musicals, this forerunner of the modern music video smashed the mould.
Part musical bonanza, part laugh-out-loud farce, part satirical social document.

As invigorating and funny now as it was on its original release half a century ago, A Hard Day's Night offers both a perfect showcase for the Beatles and an intriguing snapshot of fast-changing, early-1960s British society.

It's pure joy as I Should Have Known Better, And I Love Her and Tell Me Why pour out over footage of thousands of screaming, weeping schoolgirls with bouffant hair and miniskirts pursuing John, Paul, George and Ringo.
The results remain pop perfection.
Pure, delirious, irresistible joy.
The whole movie is an ecstatic mix of serendipity and invention. The Beatles were ready for their cinematic breakthrough.
The movie never feels like a nostalgia trip. It moves, breathes and sings with life.
Critic Andrew Sarris wasn't just playing the fanboy when he described this movie as 'The Citizen Kane of jukebox musicals.' He just might have been selling it short.
an art film and an exploitation film, a comedy and a musical, a celebration of the Beatles and a satire of their fame and fortune

A Hard Day's Night is a chance to experience to the joyous, early days of pop - while at the same time noting how the pressures of re-energising national life were beginning to close in on the enchanting innocence of youth.

Stuffed full of incident and the sort of joke-book-crossed-with-Goonery humour which the Beatles seem to have made their own, but for the most part the pace is too frantic, and the Beatles too inexperienced in comic techniques to make the most of it.

review_content: [The film] gives the seminal early '90s hip-hop group as stylish and intimate a treatment as fans could hope for, paying as much attention to the music in question as it does to the characters who made it.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Starts out rather conventionally and builds into one of the most engaging music docs in years.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Seminal hip-hop act gets due praise in solid bio-doc.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Even as an "18 months later" epilogue ensures us that everything's hunky dory, this is one surprisingly grim celebration of a group Rapaport obviously loves.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: While indulging in plenty of back-in-the-day remembrances, the film also creates a vivid image of the hip-hop that [A Tribe Called Quest] loved and also couldn't wait to subvert.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Director Rapaport captures these intimate dynamics with startling depth, and the band members provide candid interviews that are amazing in their honesty and emotional insight.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: A welcome blast of '90s nostalgia, taking us back to a time - and a sound - that pulsates with optimism.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: ...is a galvanizing documentary capable of sending audience members out on personal musical quests of their own.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: A phenomenal documentary.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: You'll definitely leave the movie hoping [A Tribe Called Quest] will work out their differences to make more music together sometime in the future.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: As an introduction to A Tribe Called Quest and a history of a very particular side of hip-hop, this is pretty hard to beat.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Rapaport deserves credit for making a movie that's neither exploitative nor puffy, and in which we find ourselves rooting for these two friends to get over themselves and work things out.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: But unlike so many movies about the rise and fall of successful bands, this one manages to capture the thrill of discovery that A Tribe Called Quest enjoyed, at least in their early years.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: The film serves both as a welcome document and reminder of the group in its prime, while also creating a portrait of lives still in motion, grown men trying to move on from yet respect the work of their younger selves.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: it's Rapaport's mistake to spend so much time and energy unpacking something so much more obvious, and so much less interesting, than Tribe's music.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Rapaport, a longtime Quest fan, clearly admires Tip. He's just too forthright a storyteller to bury the tale of the quartet's acrimonious unraveling.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: A hip-hop version of The Rolling Stones' 'Gimme Shelter' and one of the best music docs to come out in recent years. Whether you love hip hop or not, this is a documentary not to be missed and one that will not be forgotten.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Even those who never joined the cult of A Tribe Called Quest will find this clear-eyed chronicle of their career irresistible.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Rapaport, in his feature directorial debut, does an admirable job recounting the group's formation and dissecting its dissolution.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: "Beats, Rhymes & Life" is a must for hip-hop heads. Others will either be won over or left wondering what all the fuss is about.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: A reminder, part "Behind the Music" and part something better, that even artists professing love and togetherness have a hard time keeping it going.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Rapaport smartly focuses on the yin-and-yang duo of Q-Tip and Phife Dawg, the group's lead rappers, and a fascinating study in contrasts.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Tribe's music takes a backseat to power struggle and personality conflict.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: An outstanding effort, and one of the more honest band biopics in recent years.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: An entertaining discussion backed by awesomely laid-back tracks ... Chronicles a creative, jazz-influenced scene of hip-hop heads that saw the music as the cake, not the icing.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: There is a love/hate relationship within A Tribe Called Quest
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Even as the band implodes, "Beats" flows as smoothly as Q-Tip on "Verses From the Abstract." It's the tension between the group's core members that really propels the film forward.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Either mandatory rap-nerd masturbation material or the most boring movie imaginable about that group with the song you liked in middle school.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: The band's politically charged hits still sound as fresh as when they were recorded, and their side projects may have improved with age. I had to download Jungle Brothers' "Black Is Black" the minute I left the theater.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: The emotional honesty Rapaport captures on screen comes off as real, a cut above standard-issue Behind the Music drama in terms of believability.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Somewhat against the odds, Rapaport manages to parlay his access and sycophancy into the plaint of a concerned fan: Please, fellas, squash this.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: A surprisingly concise and eloquent look at hip-hop itself, abetted by analytical contributions from some of the genre's most popular artists.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: I approached "Beats, Rhymes & Life: The Travels of A Tribe Called Quest" with a music lover's curiosity and a film lover's fondness for documentaries. I was not disappointed on either count.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: There are scenes toward the end of the movie that hint at a fuzzier tomorrow for Tribe, but you leave appreciating the music as it was, not hoping for anything else.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: It's a doozy.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: The movie gets the beats and rhymes down pat, but the life part is a little messy. Oh well, two out of three ain't bad.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: There's nothing new about the bickering between lead rappers Q-Tip and Phife, or their redundant breakup-and-reunion cycle. It helps that these lyricists are our key narrators, so at least they add wit and humour to their brief history.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Good vibes propel what is a fairly straightforward account of the band's formation, album output, and acrimonious breakup.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: It tells a real story that is both complex and coherent, putting ATCQ's impact on the level of what Dylan and The Beatles provided in their respective moments in musical history. And the argument is well made.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: If you want to know what hip-hop is all about, this 'rapumentary' is a fine place to start.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Even if you think you don't like hip-hop you may find yourself captivated by the musicality of A Tribe Called Quest, and that alone is reason to watch this documentary...
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Respectful but not idolatrous, this is one 'Behind the Music' piece that even those who have never heard of the group can appreciate.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Thanks to a particularly even-handed job by director Michael Rapaport, the story emerges as compelling, even for non-fans in the audience.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Despite accusations of nearly succumbing to spotlighting beefs over beats, the film comes off as an honest representation of a great group that's not to be forgotten.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: A combination of timing, access, a visual aesthetic that reflects ATCQ's Afrocentric "surface philosophy" (as the crew's look is described) and, most importantly, story-conscious editing elevates the doc above the norm.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Rapaport gets at the dynamics of a group that struggles even now to get along well enough to get paid - again.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: That mood of musical unity, of a sonic movement, is incredible, vibrantly recounted in Beats. It's more than just a documentary, it's a time capsule of hip hop originality and confidence.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: The movie's value is in informing and illuminating, not provoking.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: It's difficult to get a grasp on just what audience this documentary is made for.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: An adoring, though enlightening, look at the tumultuous run of the influential hip-hop group.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: This documentary therefore did exactly what a good music doco should do: brought people like me up to speed and, according to reports from more serious hip hop fans in the audience, provided lots of information that wasn't previously well known.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Maybe I'm just a sucker for good old fashioned hip-hop, but I found Michael Rapaport's totally-by-the-numbers music doco [Beats, Rhymes & Life: The Travels of A Tribe Called Quest] absolutely compelling.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Warning: The bassline Ron Carter contrived for the classic cut 'Buggin' Out' is about as easy to dislodge from your brain as a 'Night Gallery' earwig.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: This authorized documentary is more of a celebration of the legendary Queens quartet than a serious exploration of their art. But considering how brilliant they were at their peak, it's hard to disagree with the general sentiment.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Rapaport, clearly a fan, is able to capture both the ongoing love and the tension within the band.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Rappaport covers a huge spectrum of voices and opinions, and the themes he explores get into personal relationships -- something everyone can relate to.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: While it's uncertain if A Tribe Called Quest will ever get back together and play again, it's quite certain fans will love and appreciate BEATS, RHYMES & LIFE: THE TRAVELS OF A TRIBE CALLED QUEST as their final encore.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: [I]t might have been nice if the documentary had worked a bit harder to find a real internal narrative.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: It shows with close detail the inner troubles of one of the most influential groups in modern hip-hop, and how they all work and strive to remain an important part of that genre's future.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: ...suffers from an egregiously "inside" sensibility that ensures neophytes will periodically be left scratching their heads at the whole thing.
A celebration of Peter Pan-like spirits who felt the freedom to express themselves before anybody cared.
Aaron Rose and Joshua Leonard don't properly contextualize this mini-scene within the larger art world, nor provide basic background on their speakers.
Regardless of Rose's intentions, his underachieving airiness is both entertaining and perfectly fitting for the slacker ennui of his clique's rising years.

The cultural time capsule doubles as a testament to the joys of outsiders bonding, with interviewees emphasizing how they finally felt like they belonged somewhere after years of asphyxiating alone on the fringe.
a celebration of rude and raw art and the kinetic charge of experiencing something fresh and undefiled
Pleasing though less-than-profound homage.
A product of the movement as much as an ode to it, the film is a gem because of the immaturity and intimacy that it shares with those featured in it.
[An] alternately winsome and irritating documentary about the art scene that grew out of the Alleged Gallery on Manhattan's Lower East Side in the 1990s.
Some of the art is probably interesting, but Rose's own video-influenced filmmaking style leaves little time for inspection or reflection.
[A] pleasant film, which sings the praises of nonconformity.
Though [Director] Mr. Rose can't be blamed for waxing nostalgic, he can't much expect us to care about so fawning and self-serving a document.
It succeeds intermittently and is reasonably enlightening, but whether audiences are really going to warm up to the individuals presented here is questionable.
An absorbing look at how a circle of dispossessed young artists from the 1990s eventually found its way to mainstream success.

The film's score, by Money Mark, is an entertainment in itself.
One of the year's best documentaries.

On your deathbed you will want back the time it takes to see this one.

An amiable portrait of the artist as a scruffy slacker, and a useful jumping off point for anyone interested in investigating some of the cultural issues that marked the 1990s and the start of the new millennium.
Like the art scene it documents, Beautiful Losers is chaotic, anarchic, rambling and populated by charismatic freaks with statement T-shirts, complicated haircuts and impossibly rare trainers.
You can't help but feel like a bit of an eye-rolling parent, wondering if a few of them might benefit from a proper job and a light slap.
The affection these people have for each other is what makes Beautiful Losers (the name is taken from one of their shows) so attractive.
Prioritising the self over the job means Beautiful Losers is rarely more than a compendium of loveliness and apology.
As you watch the movie wholeheartedly and uncritically celebrate the group's "nonconformist" ethos (shouldn't someone gently break it to them?), you can feel the energy being sucked out of you.
A shamelessly self-promoting homage documentary to a like-minded group of rebel pop culture artists, who work together in a NYC collective but do independent work.
The whole ethos portrayed in this film seems to be of a tightly knit group, referencing and re-referencing each other ad infinitum.

A vivid, fluorescent-colored portrait of a sane man possessed with insane creativity.

A buoyant, engaging, visually alluring portrait of the Tennessee-born White ...
Though the movie isn't wildly original, its time-tested, artistic mantra of "just go out there and do it" is hard to resist.

An embraceable tale of childhood mischief, teenage rebellion, award-winning creativity and enduring imagination.

Beauty is Embarrassing is a funny, enormously entertaining film, built around an autobiographical show White performs for a theater audience.

These moments elevate Beauty Is Embarrassing beyond mere tribute to an undersung artist into a far rarer thing: a glimpse into the galvanizing effect art -- good art, bad art, fine art, folk art, or 5th-grader art -- can have.

An amiable if not especially urgent celebration of the life and work of Wayne White.

Neil Berkeley's infectiously affectionate portrait of artist, puppeteer and genially profane provocateur Wayne White.

review_content: Providing an inspiration for active retirement, the ex-Harlem Renaissance chorus girls profiled in docu Been Rich All My Life are still shaking booty while most of their contemporaries can only shuffle their walkers.

Heather Lyn MacDonald's TV-grade documentary, a familiar mix of taking-head interviews and archival material, documents the Silver Belles' determination to stay on their feet but is awfully reticent when it comes to race.
The Silver Belles, five former Harlem chorus girls who are still bustin' a move despite their advanced ages, are the best kind of company there is.
They're frank, funny, resilient and altogether captivating.

Been Rich All My Life, an admiring portrait of the Silver Belles, a troupe of veteran Harlem tap dancers between the ages of 84 and 96, is a valuable historical document and a useful how-to movie about making the most of old age.

While it's enjoyable on it's own terms, there's really no reason to go all the way to the film forum and plunk down twelve bucks to see this thing, when you could probably see it on public TV in a year or two.
Been Rich All My Life has a soft, golden glow, but it could have been much richer.
These women deserve some fond acclaim for their attempts to conquer age.
Under director Heather Lyn MacDonald, the film is generic and uninspired, better suited to public TV than the big screen.

Though the stripped-down style of Heather Lyn MacDonald's documentary doesn't quite do justice to her fabulous heroines, the extraordinary energy of the five former chorus girls she profiles provides plenty of fuel.
What's onscreen comes across as little more than home-movie footage of old acquaintances getting together now and again.
Five African-American women dancers strut their stuff and revel in their camaraderie and fulfilling careers doing what they love best.
A treasure that celebrates remarkable women with a unparalleled zest for life.
Good times and bum times, they've seen it all and they're still here. Lucky us.
A richly uplifting if somewhat rambling portrait of indomitableness in the face of old age and infirmity, Been Rich All My Life will be inspirational to young and old alike.
The film could be more adept and probing, but the ladies -- Cleo Hayes, Marion Coles, Elaine Ellis, Fay Ray, and Geri Kennedy -- are delightful.
This is a sweet documentary about a small group of women who've danced their way through life.

If you only watched the first half of Been Rich All My Life, you might walk away thinking it's a so-so documentary about another fascinating, underreported piece of Harlem history. And you'd be at least half right in that assessment.
Reminds us that every life contains many acts worth hearing about, not just a select few.
This is a film about brave women who left home as teenagers and have been on their own ever since. Now, nearing the end of that road, they face their inevitable decline with a cheerful vivacity.
It's a modest but highly enjoyable tribute.
Because Been Rich follows a well-hoofed path, there aren't a lot of surprises, but the women make for good company.

MacDonald seems less interested in the Silver Belles' past than their inspirational present. Eventually, the inevitable broken hips and dizzy spells take their toll, but those who remain seem determined to shuffle-step their way into the sunset.
[MacDonald's] subjects -- former black chorus girls from Harlem's golden age, when the Cotton Club and the Apollo Theater ruled New York nightlife -- are utterly captivating.
At a time in their lives when their contemporaries are bouncing great-grandchildren on their knees, these Harlem divas of dance are bouncing their booties around.

An enchanting, if bittersweet, memoir which seamlessly interweaves wistful, tenderhearted reflections with archival film footage and the readily-observable harsh realities associated with advanced age to yield a splendid slice of African-American history.
It's a credit to MacDonald that she provides a little-known view of Harlem's halcyon days, but what's missing is the pith and marrow: We feel that the women still elude us.
The rhythm of life is a powerful beat - and this affectionate and revealing documentary is sure to get even the most world-weary feet tapping.
MacDonald doesn't let the story get syrupy or maudlin. But the brief run time doesn't let us get to know the dancers as well as we might like.
A lovely story that's sweet, funny and heartfelt -- and man does it sound good.

...director John Carney is traveling over the same ground as he did with Once, though the results are far less potent...Can A Song Save Your Life? is a rhetorical question in the grand scheme of a film that offers little stakes.
Plays like an endless and quickly tiresome string of movie montages.
A warm-hearted pleasure with a whole lot of soul, and effortlessly propelled forward by charming and compassionate performances by Keira Knightley and Mark Ruffalo.
The film's quiet pleasures creep up on you.
Will leave a smile on the face of even the most cynical viewers. Impossible not to like.

I'm glad, I seriously am, that John Carney wants to make deeply and embarrassingly sincere musical movies, and I hope he keeps on making them, but let's also hope he realizes that when it comes to Once, once was enough.
By the end of this movie I was so far in the tank for it that my opinion probably can't be trusted.
For a movie that could have come off like a Hollywood version of something beautiful and tiny, it's actually quite successful.
Another upbeat outing in which characters strum their way through tricky emotional situations.
Moving along at a reasonably engaging pace, it foregrounds the actor's investment in the scenario and makes it relatable.

Could just one number, performed weedily by Keira Knightley at the beginning of this romcom, cause your body to self-combust at the prospect of enduring 90-odd minutes of a movie obsessed with authenticity but as phoney as a Miley Cyrus dance routine?
Can a Song Save Your Life? is overproduced, and more than a little fake. But it carries a sweet, and catchy tune that will likely win you over
There are times when the thing you want most is not a big, important movie but a simple, beautiful story told with sensitivity, warmth, humor and a big heart.
Songs and films save my life every day, and I suspect John Carney's latest will be embraced by audiences everywhere who feel the same way.
Carney can get himself out of structural strife by populating his film with likeable actors and having them play pleasant music. But only once.
It's a film that lives in the high and not in the comedown, even though its characters are often stalled and wallowing.
False moments far outweigh the genuine ones ...
John "Once" Carney may be replaying his greatest hit here, but Keira sings. Keira sings!

All that prickly inner conflict Ruffalo is so adept at suggesting? Cheery Begin Again wants none of it, offering instead lots of scenes of two characters we don't believe could ever exist arguing about authenticity in pop music.
A sweet, engaging film which, if a tad too shaggy, is a warm, funny change of pace from most summer fare.
An enchanting musical adventure amounting to the best kept cinematic secret of the summer! At least until now.
This is a real love story that's not about consummation or certainty, a variety we've all experienced in real life that only occasionally shows up in the movies.
A romantic drama that captures and conveys the healing power of music.

Familiar contemporary spin on the "Let's make it in the music biz" sub-genre benefits from an adoring abundance of downtown New York locations and another committed performance from Mark Ruffalo as a seriously distressed former label big shot.

Ms. Knightley isn't remotely believable as a bike-riding pop singer. The saving grace is Mark Ruffalo, the only actor on the premises who shows any grit or passion for his character or for the music business.
Begin Again [has] an approach that's very commercial, which is ironic when one considers its plot.
Begin Again doesn't quite have the same magic of Once, but it's a sweet and cuddly crowd-pleaser highlighted by a pair of great performances and some catchy tunes.

Just when you are ready to completely write off "Begin Again," the music starts to play, the camera takes it all in and makes us a part of it, and the film's unpersuasive emotions don't seem to matter as much.
A large part of the problem is that the music, which is supposed to provide heart, soul and artistic bona fides, ranges from passable to terrible.
Both laughable and sweet.
It's a film you have to meet at least half-way. but once I did, I reveled in the charm, the romance, and most of all the bevy of terrific songs.

It's rare to find a movie that uses music to define love without sentimentalizing it. But Begin Again, with songs by Glen Hansard and New Radicals frontman Gregg Alexander, is a wonderfully appealing exception.
Earnest to a fault and afraid to say something that's actually honest.
Knightley does fine work, but she's been miscast. Her innate sophistication undermines the movie's intentions right off the bat.
The film's original title was the not-entirely-rhetorical question Can A Song Save Your Life? Carney makes it clear that in his opinion, yes, it can.
Little more than a corny, overstuffed, "let's put on a show" musical.
If "Once" was a bracing blast of cool spring water, "Begin Again" is a can of Fanta. If "Once" was a piano, "Begin Again" is a keytar. If "Once" was Otis Redding, "Begin Again" is Bruno Mars.
Overall a darling, unassuming film that strikes powerfully resonant emotional chords.
Both Ruffalo and Knightley are perfect in their respective roles; in lesser hands, their characters could have become too predictable, too cliched.
Enough satisfying chemistry between its two leads as well as another terrific soundtrack, which makes it easier to overlook some of its less credible moments.
There's plenty of good to watch here, but this time around Carney's soul seems to be missing.
"Begin Again" feels more like a glorified retread of "Once" than something freshly imagined.
Music-heavy film explores reinvention and forgiveness.
Carney's specialty is inching toward clichs, backing away from them, and inching back. He's not as pure as he thinks he is, but the footsie is very entertaining.
"Begin Again" makes for easy-breezy entertainment.
There's something charming, even comforting about its predictability, and sweet about its tone.
Ruffalo and Knightley make an engaging pair of colleagues and their musical adventure together results in an enchanting, gently funny and occasionally poignant story.
Exactly the inspiring, uplifting movie I needed to see this month. It has been a rough summer, so I needed to be reminded that there's always room for new inspiration and new relationships.
The first great American film this year that can't be turned into a video game. It deserves to become a sleeper hit, and has a well-balanced blend of commercial and art-house qualities.

Born Again's most glaring weakness, however, comes from the mere fact that this has already been done, better, by the same filmmaker. It's nice to see him exploring similar material, but if you've seen Once, you've already seen the superior film.
a wistful breeze of a film, the perfect antidote to summer's cacaphonous blockbusters.

Boy already met girl, girl already left boy, that was "Once." What can a filmmaker do after that? John Carney doesn't fully succeed Twice, but there are sweet and knowing moments throughout his latest romance about songwriting and a city.
Carney is wonderful at evoking the joy of music, its healing powers, and the way it connects us to each other and the universe.
A movie that mocks artistic sellouts and then sells out itself is like a cop who chases a criminal before accepting a bribe to let him go.
"Begin Again" may not always swing, but it makes up for that in sincerity and a welcome willingness to ambush expectations.
"Begin Again" is pleasantly predictable if you're in an undemanding mood. If you're not, it's unbearable, like hearing a treasured folk song given a Hot 97 makeover.
Carney is on to something in "Begin Again," some handle on a particular truth he's exploring, and he remains faithful to it through the finish.
Carney deserves great credit for the movie's clever, layered structure, and for resisting a few obvious plot turns along the way. Lightning doesn't strike, but sunshine works, too.
"Begin Again" is an ode to the indie-rock spirit, but its music -- written by Carney and others -- is as safe, smooth and Starbucks-friendly as Norah Jones.
Another nice musical spin by Carney on the conventions of quasi-romantic dramedy.
The elements of the story interlace in delightful, heartwarming, human ways, all led by the music.

Sincerity is missing, replaced by routine and miscasting, and while the songs are pulled off with polish, the rest of the screenplay flounders, hunting for emotional harmony that's never truly believable.
Begin Again doesn't fully trust the magic Dan sees in music and, as a result, too often reverts to the banal of declaring what doesn't need to be said.
The cast is, to a person, so likable and chummy that you want everyone to succeed. And the songs are hook-laden, easygoing numbers that are genuinely enjoyable.
Once was enough. Twice is pushing it.

It's no Once - hell, it's not even Nick & Norah's Infinite Playlist - but if one is willing to accept the poppy indulgence of it all, Begin Again is equally easy on the eyes and ears. In other words, it's the Maroon 5 of movies.
Begin Again is a more polished studio effort with much bigger stars, and yet it recaptures much of the magic that made Once so special.
There is an air of fantasy to the film, but there's far less cheap sentimentality than one might expect.
Your heart and feet won't be able to resist what might be called-despite the assumed objections of author Nick Hornby-a High Fidelity for the iPod generation.

I've always really like Ruffalo and especially Knightley as performers and they bring just the right touches to their characters not only to make them seem human, but also able to engage most viewers. (Full Content Review for Parents also available)
There has to be a little bit of magic in 'Begin Again;' how else can I explain getting sucked into a movie I've seen a thousand times before?
Doggedly indie but unpretentious, "Begin Again" is one of the best movies I've seen about the music industry and the ways it changes people whose paths diverge.
In a complete reversal from "Once," it's the story, not the songs, that carries "Begin Again."
Begin Again is corny, improbable and generally a great deal of fun.
Basically, it's the cinematic equivalent of purchasing an entire album, enjoying the entire thing, but over time realizing that you only care for about half the songs.
"Begin Again" sets out to be a feel-good movie and, despite such obvious intentions, it thoroughly succeeds.
Can a song save your life? And can an impossibly mushy, mawkish movie make you feel good? The answer to the second question, anyway, is yes.

With its cornball narrative and unlikely developments, Begin Again is about as grounded in reality as How to Train Your Dragon 2. Yet the picture is so warmhearted and generous of spirit that it's easy to overlook its contrivances.

It's so schizophrenic, it's like listening to a discombobulated speed freak recalling his life story. But in haphazardly mixing narrative styles, Carney cannot create enough of a diversion to disguise the fact that 'Begin Again' is merely another 'Once.'

The movie is moderately obsessed with the ideal of authenticity, which is a rather awkward position to champion given that it is a calculatedly more-commercial, less-authentic variation of a film, Once, that Carney had already made.
"Once" again - buy the soundtrack.
Knightley and Ruffalo make for one of the most unusual engaging couples of the year.
You can't really blame writer-director John Carney for trying, but despite a few very nice moments, this bigger, slicker follow-up mostly argues that Once should have been enough.

All round, it is more contrived and self-aware in order to make certain redemptions seem richer, but there are some clever scenes, and it is a nice, uplifting, tuneful, often funny and enjoyable film.
Carney knows exactly what he's doing here and knows exactly what real people can't do.
Keira Knightley's singing voice, a little too girlish, a bit too breathy yet somehow still lovely, is Begin Again at its essence.
Its soft-rock bonhomie [prevails] over a story that often registers as trite or naive.
Part of the problem is the change of location; what seemed enchanting in Dublin feels twee in New York.
Fans of the Oscar-winning 2006 Irish film Once (and its more recent stage-musical adaptation) may find this American drama a little derivative, but it's a strong story in its own right.
Begin Again is a New York fairytale but a fairly irresistible one thanks to the actors.
For what is essentially a quite predictable endeavour for Carney, Begin Again does certainly throw in the odd surprise or two, particularly where the romantic narrative is concerned.

The songs, then, are make-or-break, and the track list Carney and Gregg Alexander have produced is a triumph: mellow summer pop and wistful, stripped-down ballads arranged around Knightley's surprisingly alluring vocals.
The gentle lightning of Once doesn't strike twice for Carney, but his latest music movie has charm beneath its slick surface - and Knightley and Ruffalo harmonise just fine.
Keira Knightley plays Greta, a Norah Jones-like singer-songwriter... It's a typically brave performance from an actress who is always prepared to try anything.
At times, the scenes are so canned they feel like soap opera. But the movie does have its fair share of decent moments thanks to Ruffalo and co-star Catherine Keener.
It's all a bit easy - though quite nicely performed - and Knightley is never entirely convincing ...
Can a meaningful glance mean as much as a kiss? In this film, it can, and that's enough.
No matter how thin the drama, or thick the performances, the film's firefly-in-a-jar, midsummer night's whimsy and heart-on-its-sleeve optimism hath charms ...
Keira Knightley brings a sweet soul to John Carney's delightful sort-of sequel to his low-fi hit, Once.
The film is a fairy tale: sentimental but enjoyable if you put a few protective fingers in front of your face to avoid being slurped to death.

Ruffalo comes on heavy with the shambolic self-pity, but seems just right for the character he's playing. Knightley, except for the dismayingly tense jaw-cortortion of her singing routines, positively shines.
John Carney returns with another feature-length music video, turning the surprising charm of his debut, Once, a novel take on the modern musical romance, into a shameless gimmick. Just call it Twice.
Knightley's bullish Britishness and Ruffalo's bruised charm provide a pleasingly gentle, unsentimental chemistry and, heck, there's even James Corden on a kazoo.
The result is a film that, while fitting into various great traditions, still bears the unmistakable thumbprint of a singular film-maker.
Carney's latest isn't quite the equal of Once, but who could have twice bottled that lightning?
Irish writer-director John Carney is a master at depicting musicians on the cusp of something special.
This soulful outing is sure to please music lovers. And isn't that everyone?
Keira Knightley sings and so does the movie!
A decent feel-good flick that features also decent music. The real reason to see it is the acting especially that of Mark Ruffalo who gives a career best performance.
A cheery charmer that brings a smile to the face.
Fans of Once - or, indeed, anyone with a heart - will be swept away by the gentle, sweet-but-sad story.
Begin Again is a not-entirely-successful movie about not selling out; it's a theme that must concern Carney deeply.
It's a movie that is painfully sincere and free of guile, with as close to a happy ending as these characters could ever get. If you like musicals, well, here's a good one.

The wholesome, hopeful, let's-put-on-a-show enthusiasm may sound hokey but it's actually infectiously joyful. At the same time, Carney roughs up the edges just enough to make this fairy tale seem somewhat accessible and realistic.
Another sappy but engaging musical fable from the Irish writer and director John Carney, who made "Once."
I found it moving, funny and really rather charming, provoking more than enough laughter and tears to dispel my underlying anxieties about the "live" performances.
a light and dancing comedy about fresh starts
A mostly pleasant but deeply flawed little film that gets by on its stars and a sense of generosity.
The trouble with this movie -- aside from its lack of visual wonder and musical shape -- is that you don't trust its priorities.
...breezy and consistently watchable...
In its best moments - which are not infrequent - is appealing mostly on the backs of watching interesting, capable people going on with their business in an engaged, focused manner.
This is the kind of film that lifts your spirits. If you've had a bad day or are generally feeling down, it will cheer you up. If you're already feeling happy, it will make you even happier.
Makes for a pleasant time killer about how music brings people together.
You'll find a mismatched pair to pull for and a lot of sincerity in this musical romance by the creator of Once.
A hugely satisfying ode to entrepreneurial creativity, and a glorious love letter to New York City and the art it inspires. I love this movie so much.
The film comes alive when the focus is on the music. There's a heartfelt authenticity to the production numbers.
People who love music, people who love great films, and people who love both, are sure to love 'Begin Again,' an exquisite film by John Carney, who wrought the equally superb 'Once.'
Thankfully Begin Again doesn't take the predictable routes; it seems to actively reject the easy romantic tropes.
Music is the driver of this utterly charming film about songs, lost stars and being alone in New York City
Carney's script suffers from more than a few contrivances, but the charm of the performances - both spoken and sung - shines through
